Elijah Lee, Independent Financial Advisor at Phillip Securities (Jurong East Lite)Top Contributor (Sep)Level 9. God of WisdomUpdated 3w agoHi Melissa, some of the things you need to consider:The frequency of income distribution and whether there is any financial engineering to boost the numbersThe yield relative to the peers in the same categoryLoan maturity profileInterest cover ratioLease expiry and Occupancy of their propertiesLand lease (99 years or freehold?)Local assets or foreign?Do you have a particular reason to DCA into REITs? Unless your DCA amount is large, you are looking at the costs of investing eating into your returns.0 comments6

Allan LeeLevel 2. RookieAnswered 3w agoYou may also want to consider their DPU. A good REITs increases its DPU over time. Frequency of Rights issue, as it dilutes your share. A well-managed REITs should not be always asking me for money. Generally, a good REITs should always give you capital appreciation together with dividends.0 comments0

Jonathan Chia Guangrong, Fund Manager at JCG FundLevel 6. MasterAnswered 3w agoA good question to ask yourself is are you overpaying for the stock. REITs are having a strong year so far. Find an entry point when the spread between nav and the current price is low.Another thing is the REIT sector. Are you comfortable with the outlook of the sector your chosen REIT is in?Look out for funky management decisions as well (case in point - OUE). Or is management prudent? Is the REIT DPU stable? Growing over the years?Some basic things to look out for before investing in a REIT. Hope this helps0 comments0
